awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: CAS: A light-based, energy-generating, carbon removal process
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project includes reducing the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and sequestering them permanently or reusing them to make sustainable chemicals. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the world’s most authoritative body of climate scientists and policymakers, has declared that billions of tons of carbon dioxide must be removed from the atmosphere annually by 2050 to prevent global temperatures from exceeding 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels, avoiding the worst impacts of climate change. If successful, this research would provide a path to gigaton-scale carbon removal. The low energy requirements of the process could allow for deployment in locations distant from large energy infrastructure to bring the benefits and jobs of a new carbon removal industry to communities most affected by weather related events.

This project will commercialize a fundamentally new approach to carbon removal. The vast amount of carbon dioxide locked in seawater remains dissolved if it stays near neutral pH, but outgases spontaneously when acidified. This process uses a light-triggered reversible photoacid as a low-energy means to temporarily acidify seawater and drive out carbon dioxide, which can then be stored or used in industry. The proprietary photoacid at the heart of the process changes its structural conformation when exposed to visible light and releases a proton. The resulting increase in acidity upon illumination provides the proton driving force for carbon capture. Sunlight not absorbed by the photoacid can be used to generate electricity with embedded polysilicon solar cells. Two aspects of the system need to be improved for the process to be deployed at scale. The photoacid’s resistance to degradation needs to be increased or a simple and scalable process to recover the degraded photoacid needs to be demonstrated. In addition, the ion exchange membranes used in the initial lab prototype are expensive and need to be replaced with cheaper and higher flux membranes. If successful, these developments would lead to a scalable and affordable carbon removal process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Decarbonizing the global economy is the Apollo Moon Shot of this century. In addition to widespread adoption of renewable energy, every serious plan to keep global temperatures below dangerous limits requires carbon dioxide removal (CDR) at the billion-ton- per-year scale. Yet there is a giant gap between this pressing need for CDR and existing capabilities, which are costly and energy intensive.

Banyu Carbon’s novel approach to CDR is based on the use of a light-triggered reversible photoacid as a low energy means to remove carbon dioxide (CO2) from seawater, where it is 140 times more concentrated than in the atmosphere. Removing carbon from the surface ocean can withdraw a similar amount of CO2 from the air because of the movement of gases between the air and surface ocean. The vast amount of CO2 locked in seawater remains dissolved if it stays near neutral pH, but outgases spontaneously when acidified by our photoacids. These compounds change their structural conformation and release a proton when exposed to light, becoming 1000-fold more acidic than in the dark. Only the proton is transferred in our process since the photoacid solution is separated from the seawater by an ion exchanger. This approach keeps our photoacid physically separate from seawater. We plan to discharge seawater with less CO2 than incoming seawater because we will be removing CO2, the main cause of climate change, from this water. The decarbonated seawater will then draw more CO2 from the atmosphere to replace the CO2 we removed.

Two aspects of the system need to be improved for the Banyu Carbon process to be deployed at scale. The photoacid’s resistance to hydrolysis needs to be increased or a simple and scalable process to recover the hydrolyzed photoacid needs to be demonstrated. In addition, the ion exchange membranes used in our initial lab prototype are expensive and need to be replaced with a fundamentally cheaper and higher flux alternative. Solving these fundamental research problems will enable the development, scale-up, and testing of an operational field pilot under real word conditions, which is itself a pre-requisite for the deployment of a first of kind commercial facility.

As part of this NSF award, Banyu Carbon developed a new more affordable ion exchange process based on commercially available materials. This process completely eliminates costly membranes from the ion exchange process. We then demonstrated that our new approach could achieve key performance targets under expected operating conditions. This ion exchange process is now ready for testing at a larger scale and will lay the groundwork for deployment of a real-word pilot demonstration of our carbon removal technology. Banyu Carbon also developed multiple independent approaches to improve photoacid longevity. We successfully synthesized new photoacid molecules with improved hydrolysis rates. We also demonstrated a novel recycling approach where degraded photoacids are recovered and heated to re-make active photoacids.

Banyu Carbon successfully met the main goals of this Phase I proposal because we developed a promising alternative to ion exchange membranes and improved photoacid longevity. Solving these problems is commercially important because these issues are the biggest cost drivers for our process. The work from this award, taken together with our other technical developments,  is propelling Banyu Carbon to rapidly advance and commercialize our low-cost carbon removal process.

  • Our process uses sunlight to drive a chemical reaction that causes CO2 to be released from seawater. Sunlight not needed for the chemistry is used to generate solar electricity. The liberated CO2 is permanently stored underground. The reversible photoacids driving the process are easy to produce.
